title: Ticket #5957: startd policies always_run_jobs and limit_job_runtimes do not work
description:
On an execute node one of whose config.d files contains 

use POLICY:Always_Run_Jobs
use POLICY:Limit_Job_Runtimes
MAX_JOB_RUNTIME = (24*$(HOUR))

and in condor_config 

MINUTE = 60
HOUR   = (60 * $(MINUTE))
DAY    = (24 * $(HOUR))

we observe that jobs are not, in fact, retired after 24 hours as the documentation for 8.5.7 (p. 193 in the PDF) claims. 

slot2_15@execute2024.nemo.uwm.edu LINUX      X86_64 Claimed   Retiring  2.860  2048  4+21:56:33

The StartLog on the node. 

10/05/16 12:09:27 slot2_15: Got activate_claim request from shadow (172.20.1.34)
10/05/16 12:09:28 slot2_15: Remote job ID is 1126438.0
10/05/16 12:09:28 slot2_15: Got universe "VANILLA" (5) from request classad
10/05/16 12:09:28 slot2_15: State change: claim-activation protocol successful
10/05/16 12:09:28 slot2_15: Changing activity: Idle -> Busy
10/05/16 12:09:38 slot2_15: Called deactivate_claim_forcibly()
10/05/16 12:09:38 slot2_15: State change: starter exited
10/05/16 12:09:38 slot2_15: Changing activity: Busy -> Idle
10/05/16 12:09:39 slot2_15: Got activate_claim request from shadow (172.20.1.34)
10/05/16 12:09:39 slot2_15: Remote job ID is 1126475.1
10/05/16 12:09:39 slot2_15: Got universe "VANILLA" (5) from request classad
10/05/16 12:09:39 slot2_15: State change: claim-activation protocol successful
10/05/16 12:09:39 slot2_15: Changing activity: Idle -> Busy
10/06/16 12:09:42 slot2_15: State change: PREEMPT is TRUE
10/06/16 12:09:42 slot2_15: Changing activity: Busy -> Retiring

And nothing more (it's still retiring). I intend to explore the definitions of these policies to figure out why, but the documentation seems fairly clear that these policies should allow jobs to run until the time limit, but no more.
remarks:
2016-Oct-11 10:36:00 by tpdownes:
Could ALLOW_PSLOT_PREEMPTION = True on the negotiator affected this? Recall I'm running 8.5.7 so it doesn't also need to be set elsewhere. Would this configuration setting linger in its behavior even if it were condor_reconfig'd to False?

2016-Oct-12 11:50:26 by tpdownes:
Because the job is essentially immediately entering the Retiring state, I suspect a race condition between job start and =EnteredCurrentActivity=.

Woops! Missed the change in day in the logs! It is nevertheless a fact that I am having jobs remain Retiring for a long time. Presumably until the job exits. Are these startd policies missing knobs necessary to actually limit the job runtimes?

2016-Oct-12 13:30:26 by gthain:
Note that LIMIT_JOB_RUNTIMES needs to set MaxJobRetirementTime

2016-Oct-12 13:35:06 by tlmiller:
Looks like Limit_Job_Runtime doesn't set MAXJOBRETIREMENTTIME, which trumps the PREEMPT knob it does set. Since Always_Run_Jobs sets MAXJOBRETIREMENTTIME to MAX_SIGNED_INT (or thereabouts), Limit_Job_Runtime doesn't actually limit job run time.

Do we also need to add the Retiring state to the PREEMPT expression?
